title: Your trash deserves better. These three cases show what’s possible. - Rocky Mountain Institute
summary: Landfills are a major source of methane emissions, but there are many policies and programs that can reduce these emissions while delivering powerful co-benefits. The article highlights three case studies: the state of Maryland, the city of Austin, Texas, and Sierra Nevada Brewing Company. These case studies illustrate how upstream and downstream waste management strategies can be implemented to reduce organic waste disposal in landfills and promote sustainable materials management.

business_innovation: TRUE, the article describes several business innovations, such as Sierra Nevada Brewing Company's use of an industrial on-site composter to process food waste, landscaping debris, and small amounts of hops and spent grain, and their partnership with 530 Food Rescue to facilitate food donations.
green_product: TRUE, the article describes several green products, such as the compost produced by Sierra Nevada Brewing Company's on-site composter, which is used for agricultural purposes on-site, growing produce, herbs, hops, and barley.
green_process: TRUE, the article describes several green processes, such as Sierra Nevada Brewing Company's anaerobic digestion of spent yeast at its North Carolina facility, which produces biogas that is used in boilers and microturbines, covering about 8 percent of total electricity needs.

title: How carbon markets should evolve to meet net-zero ambitions - Deloitte
summary: Several countries and states have implemented compliance carbon markets that have been successful in reducing emissions. Linking these markets can increase their effectiveness by expanding their scope and enabling progress in local jurisdictions as well as leading to price convergence. The integration of these markets can be achieved through direct or indirect linkages, and may be easier to establish between countries with similar environmental goals, economic backgrounds, and histories of mutually beneficial trade agreements.

title: Moving Beyond Net Zero to Nature Positive - BCG
summary: The Kunming-Montréal Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF) adopted by 195 countries aims to halt and reverse the global decline of nature and biodiversity. The private sector will play a vital role in achieving the targets of the GBF, which include protecting freshwater and other ecosystems and the disclosure of biodiversity impacts by companies. Companies can take four steps to answer the call to action embodied in the targets of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework and begin to reap the benefits of nature positive: establish a clear North Star for the company’s nature ambition, decide how and where to start taking action on nature, redefine and transform your company’s business models and operations, and coordinate and combine the company’s climate and nature initiatives.

title: Benefits of Carbon Pricing to Inspire Action on Net Zero | BCG - BCG
summary: Companies can use internal carbon pricing to account for their current carbon footprint, assess their carbon abatement needs, and then fund the decarbonization effort. By putting the process into the hands of the CFO and the finance function, it can be carried out with thoroughness and accuracy, and ensure that it is fully incorporated into the company's operations and abatement initiatives. Given the need to begin the decarbonization process soon, if companies are to reach their net zero goals, the time to begin is now.

title: What's Ireland doing when it comes to just transition planning? - RTE.ie
summary: There are international trends towards considering just transitions, as the world moves rapidly toward climate-neutrality. The Irish government plans for a Just Transition Commission in 2024, and the experiences of other countries in doing so provide useful lessons. Key themes gained from these experiences are to establish a strong planning framework for just transitions; incorporate scientific and expert advice into policymaking; prioritize broad public participation and stakeholder engagement; and continuously monitor and have accountability for just transition efforts.

title: Textiles 2030 announces second annual progress report - UKFT
summary: Textiles 2030, a voluntary agreement for collaborative climate action in the UK fashion and textiles industry, has released its second Annual Progress Update for 2022/23. In the first two years, 130 businesses, representing over 62% of all clothing products placed on the UK market, have signed up to the agreement, which incorporates science-based targets to transition to a circular textiles economy. The collective carbon footprint has decreased by 2% in comparison to the baseline year of 2019 but the water footprint has increased by 8% due to the increased amount of cotton used.
